technologies.name: Node.js
technologies.description: Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform, JavaScript runtime environment that executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.

technologies.name: Envoy
technologies.description: Envoy is an open-source edge and service proxy, designed for cloud-native applications.

technologies.name: Express
technologies.description: Express is a web application framework for Node.js, released as free and open-source software under the MIT License. It is designed for building web applications and APIs.

technologies.name: Google Hosted Libraries
technologies.description: Google Hosted Libraries is a stable, reliable, high-speed, globally available content distribution network for the most popular, open-source JavaScript libraries.

technologies.name: Cloudflare Browser Insights
technologies.description: Cloudflare Browser Insights is a tool that measures the performance of websites from the perspective of users.

technologies.name: Matomo Analytics
technologies.description: Matomo Analytics is a free and open-source web analytics application, that runs on a PHP/MySQL web-server.

technologies.name: jQuery
technologies.description: jQuery is a JavaScript library which is a free, open-source software designed to simplify HTML DOM tree traversal and manipulation, as well as event handling, CSS animation, and Ajax.

technologies.name: HSTS
technologies.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS.

technologies.name: Cloudflare
technologies.description: Cloudflare is a web-infrastructure and website-security company, providing content-delivery-network services, DDoS mitigation, Internet security, and distributed domain-name-server services.

technologies.name: HTTP/3
technologies.description: HTTP/3 is the third major version of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol used to exchange information on the World Wide Web.

alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header
alerts.desc: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion
alerts.desc: The page includes one or more script files from a third-party domain.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header is an opt-in header designed to counter side-channels attacks like Spectre. Resource should be specifically set as shareable amongst different origins.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Retrieved from Cache
alerts.desc: The content was retrieved from a shared cache. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

attributes.pitch: Aider les collectivits  prioriser la mise en uvre des actions les plus impactantes pour russir la transition cologique

alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header
alerts.desc: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header is an opt-in header designed to counter side-channels attacks like Spectre. Resource should be specifically set as shareable amongst different origins.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Content-Type Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Content-Type header was either missing or empty.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Retrieved from Cache
alerts.desc: The content was retrieved from a shared cache. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header is an opt-in header designed to counter side-channels attacks like Spectre. Resource should be specifically set as shareable amongst different origins.

alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set
alerts.desc: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Content-Type Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Content-Type header was either missing or empty.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

info.name: CAA Record

info.name: SPF Record - Detection
author: rxerium

author: pdteam

author: pdteam

author: pdteam

info.name: Detect SSL Certificate Issuer
author: lingtren
info.description: Extract the issuer's organization from the target's certificate. Issuers are entities which sign and distribute certificates.

info.name: SSL DNS Names
author: pdteam
info.description: Extract the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) from the target's certificate. SAN facilitates the usage of additional hostnames with the same certificate.

info.name: TLS Version - Detect
author: pdteam
pussycat0x
info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

rule.name: actions/missing-workflow-permissions
rule.full_description: Workflows should contain explicit permissions to restrict the scope of the default GITHUB_TOKEN.
rule.help:
## Overview

If a GitHub Actions job or workflow has no explicit permissions set, then the repository permissions are used. Repositories created under organizations inherit the organization permissions. The organizations or repositories created before February 2023 have the default permissions set to read-write. Often these permissions do not adhere to the principle of least privilege and can be reduced to read-only, leaving the `write` permission only to a specific types as `issues: write` or `pull-requests: write`.

## Recommendation

Add the `permissions` key to the job or the root of workflow (in this case it is applied to all jobs in the workflow that do not have their own `permissions` key) and assign the least privileges required to complete the task.

## Example

### Incorrect Usage

```yaml
name: "My workflow"
# No permissions block
```

### Correct Usage

```yaml
name: "My workflow"
permissions:
  contents: read
  pull-requests: write
```

or

```yaml
jobs:
  my-job:
    permissions:
      contents: read
      pull-requests: write
```

## References

- GitHub Docs: [Assigning permissions to jobs](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/writing-workflows/choosing-what-your-workflow-does/assigning-permissions-to-jobs).

message.text: Actions job or workflow does not limit the permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN. Consider setting an explicit permissions block, using the following as a minimal starting point: {{contents: read}}

alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: X-Frame-Options Setting Malformed
alerts.desc: An X-Frame-Options header was present in the response but the value was not correctly set.

alerts.name: Application Error Disclosure
alerts.desc: This page contains an error/warning message that may disclose sensitive information like the location of the file that produced the unhandled exception. This information can be used to launch further attacks against the web application. The alert could be a false positive if the error message is found inside a documentation page.

alerts.name: CSP: Notices
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Dangerous JS Functions
alerts.desc: A dangerous JS function seems to be in use that would leave the site vulnerable.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header is an opt-in header designed to counter side-channels attacks like Spectre. Resource should be specifically set as shareable amongst different origins.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix

alerts.name: Authentication Request Identified
alerts.desc: The given request has been identified as an authentication request. The 'Other Info' field contains a set of key=value lines which identify any relevant fields. If the request is in a context which has an Authentication Method set to "Auto-Detect" then this rule will change the authentication to match the request identified.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Content-Type Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Content-Type header was either missing or empty.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Information in URL
alerts.desc: The request appeared to contain sensitive information leaked in the URL. This can violate PCI and most organizational compliance policies. You can configure the list of strings for this check to add or remove values specific to your environment.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Session Management Response Identified
alerts.desc: The given response has been identified as containing a session management token. The 'Other Info' field contains a set of header tokens that can be used in the Header Based Session Management Method. If the request is in a context which has a Session Management Method set to "Auto-Detect" then this rule will change the session management to use the tokens identified.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.desc: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Content-Type Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Content-Type header was either missing or empty.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.desc: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is following basic search engine optimization advice. There are many additional factors Lighthouse does not score here that may affect your search ranking, including performance on [Core Web Vitals](https://web.dev/learn-web-vitals/). [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: PWA
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

attributes.name: Impact CO2
attributes.pitch: Le site internet qui vulgarise et valorise les donnes environnementales de l'ADEME

rule.name: actions/missing-workflow-permissions
rule.full_description: Workflows should contain explicit permissions to restrict the scope of the default GITHUB_TOKEN.
rule.help:
## Overview

If a GitHub Actions job or workflow has no explicit permissions set, then the repository permissions are used. Repositories created under organizations inherit the organization permissions. The organizations or repositories created before February 2023 have the default permissions set to read-write. Often these permissions do not adhere to the principle of least privilege and can be reduced to read-only, leaving the `write` permission only to a specific types as `issues: write` or `pull-requests: write`.

## Recommendation

Add the `permissions` key to the job or the root of workflow (in this case it is applied to all jobs in the workflow that do not have their own `permissions` key) and assign the least privileges required to complete the task.

## Example

### Incorrect Usage

```yaml
name: "My workflow"
# No permissions block
```

### Correct Usage

```yaml
name: "My workflow"
permissions:
  contents: read
  pull-requests: write
```

or

```yaml
jobs:
  my-job:
    permissions:
      contents: read
      pull-requests: write
```

## References

- GitHub Docs: [Assigning permissions to jobs](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/writing-workflows/choosing-what-your-workflow-does/assigning-permissions-to-jobs).

message.text: Actions job or workflow does not limit the permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN. Consider setting an explicit permissions block, using the following as a minimal starting point: {{contents: read}}

alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain Misconfiguration
alerts.desc: Web browser data loading may be possible, due to a Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) misconfiguration on the web server.

alerts.name: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header
alerts.desc: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header is a response header that prevents a document from loading any cross-origin resources that don't explicitly grant the document permission (using CORP or CORS).

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: CSP: Header & Meta
alerts.desc: The message contained both CSP specified via header and via Meta tag. It was not possible to union these policies in order to perform an analysis. Therefore, they have been evaluated individually.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

rule.name: actions/missing-workflow-permissions
rule.full_description: Workflows should contain explicit permissions to restrict the scope of the default GITHUB_TOKEN.
rule.help:
## Overview

If a GitHub Actions job or workflow has no explicit permissions set, then the repository permissions are used. Repositories created under organizations inherit the organization permissions. The organizations or repositories created before February 2023 have the default permissions set to read-write. Often these permissions do not adhere to the principle of least privilege and can be reduced to read-only, leaving the `write` permission only to a specific types as `issues: write` or `pull-requests: write`.

## Recommendation

Add the `permissions` key to the job or the root of workflow (in this case it is applied to all jobs in the workflow that do not have their own `permissions` key) and assign the least privileges required to complete the task.

## Example

### Incorrect Usage

```yaml
name: "My workflow"
# No permissions block
```

### Correct Usage

```yaml
name: "My workflow"
permissions:
  contents: read
  pull-requests: write
```

or

```yaml
jobs:
  my-job:
    permissions:
      contents: read
      pull-requests: write
```

## References

- GitHub Docs: [Assigning permissions to jobs](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/writing-workflows/choosing-what-your-workflow-does/assigning-permissions-to-jobs).

message.text: Actions job or workflow does not limit the permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN. Consider setting an explicit permissions block, using the following as a minimal starting point: {{contents: read}}

technologies.name: OVHcloud
technologies.description: OVHcloud is a global, cloud provider delivering hosted private cloud, public cloud, and dedicated server solutions.

technologies.name: HSTS
technologies.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS.

alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain Misconfiguration
alerts.desc: Web browser data loading may be possible, due to a Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) misconfiguration on the web server.

alerts.name: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header
alerts.desc: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header is a response header that prevents a document from loading any cross-origin resources that don't explicitly grant the document permission (using CORP or CORS).

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: CSP: Header & Meta
alerts.desc: The message contained both CSP specified via header and via Meta tag. It was not possible to union these policies in order to perform an analysis. Therefore, they have been evaluated individually.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

technologies.name: Sentry
technologies.description: Sentry is an open-source platform for workflow productivity, aggregating errors from across the stack in real time.

technologies.name: Node.js
technologies.description: Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform, JavaScript runtime environment that executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.

technologies.name: React
technologies.description: React is an open-source JavaScript library for building user interfaces or UI components.

technologies.name: Next.js
technologies.description: Next.js is a React framework for developing single page Javascript applications.

technologies.name: Tally
technologies.description: Tally is the simplest way to create free forms & surveys. Create any type of form in seconds, without knowing how to code, and for free.

technologies.name: Matomo Analytics
technologies.description: Matomo Analytics is a free and open-source web analytics application, that runs on a PHP/MySQL web-server.

technologies.name: Priority Hints
technologies.description: Priority Hints exposes a mechanism for developers to signal a relative priority for browsers to consider when fetching resources.

technologies.name: Webpack
technologies.description: Webpack is an open-source JavaScript module bundler.

technologies.name: PWA
technologies.description: Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are web apps built and enhanced with modern APIs to deliver enhanced capabilities, reliability, and installability while reaching anyone, anywhere, on any device, all with a single codebase.

technologies.name: Open Graph
technologies.description: Open Graph is a protocol that is used to integrate any web page into the social graph.

technologies.name: Module Federation
technologies.description: Module Federation is a webpack technology for dynamically loading parts of other independently deployed builds.

alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header
alerts.desc: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.

alerts.name: Big Redirect Detected (Potential Sensitive Information Leak)
alerts.desc: The server has responded with a redirect that seems to provide a large response. This may indicate that although the server sent a redirect it also responded with body content (which may include sensitive details, PII, etc.).

alerts.name: Cookie No HttpOnly Flag
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion
alerts.desc: The page includes one or more script files from a third-party domain.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header is an opt-in header designed to counter side-channels attacks like Spectre. Resource should be specifically set as shareable amongst different origins.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

alerts.name: Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set
alerts.desc: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix

alerts.name: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Content-Type Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Content-Type header was either missing or empty.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable but Non-Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, but will not be retrieved directly from the cache, without validating the request upstream, in response to similar requests from other users.

info.name: SPF Record - Detection
author: rxerium
info.description: An SPF TXT record was detected

info.name: DNS TXT Record Detected
author: pdteam
info.description: A DNS TXT record was detected. The TXT record lets a domain admin leave notes on a DNS server.

info.name: CAA Record
author: pdteam
info.description: A CAA record was discovered. A CAA record is used to specify which certificate authorities (CAs) are allowed to issue certificates for a domain.

info.name: NS Record Detection
author: pdteam
info.description: An NS record was detected. An NS record delegates a subdomain to a set of name servers.

info.name: MX Record Detection
author: pdteam
info.description: An MX record was detected. MX records direct emails to a mail exchange server.

info.name: DNS DMARC - Detect
author: juliosmelo
info.description: DNS DMARC information was detected.

info.name: RDAP WHOIS
author: ricardomaia
sttlr
info.description:
RDAP (Registration Data Access Protocol) is a standard defined by the IETF to replace the whois protocol
in queries for information about Internet resource records such as domain names, IP addresses, and ASNs.

info.name: Detect SSL Certificate Issuer
author: lingtren
info.description: Extract the issuer's organization from the target's certificate. Issuers are entities which sign and distribute certificates.

info.name: SSL DNS Names
author: pdteam
info.description: Extract the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) from the target's certificate. SAN facilitates the usage of additional hostnames with the same certificate.

info.name: TLS Version - Detect
author: pdteam
pussycat0x
info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

info.name: TLS Version - Detect
author: pdteam
pussycat0x
info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO

alerts.name: Vulnerable JS Library
alerts.desc: The identified library appears to be vulnerable.

alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-eval
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain Misconfiguration
alerts.desc: Web browser data loading may be possible, due to a Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) misconfiguration on the web server.

alerts.name: Application Error Disclosure
alerts.desc: This page contains an error/warning message that may disclose sensitive information like the location of the file that produced the unhandled exception. This information can be used to launch further attacks against the web application. The alert could be a false positive if the error message is found inside a documentation page.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Debug Error Messages
alerts.desc: The response appeared to contain common error messages returned by platforms such as ASP.NET, and Web-servers such as IIS and Apache. You can configure the list of common debug messages.

alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header is a response header that prevents a document from loading any cross-origin resources that don't explicitly grant the document permission (using CORP or CORS).

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

info.name: CAA Record

info.description: A CAA record was discovered. A CAA record is used to specify which certificate authorities (CAs) are allowed to issue certificates for a domain.

info.name: TLS Version - Detect
author: pdteam
pussycat0x
info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

technologies.name: Module Federation
